question:
Given:
p1: Blue is a common color.
p2: Yellow is a common color.
p3: \sqrt{3}  is irrational.
p4: 5 is irrational.

Symbolize the following propositions:
(1) Blue and yellow are both common colors.
(2) Either \sqrt{3} or 5 is irrational.
(3) Exactly one of \sqrt{3} and 5 is irrational.

Specify that only &,||,~ can be used for this question.
Please format your answers as [[ ];[ ];[ ]], where each bracketed section contains the corresponding logical expression for each proposition.
needle: Propositions are represented using p1, p2, ..., pn.
Let p1 be a proposition, the compound proposition "not p1" is represented as ~p1.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 and p2" is represented as p1&p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 or p2" is represented as p1||p2.
title: Propositional Logic Formalization
rule_content:
Propositions are represented using p1, p2, ..., pn.
Let p1 be a proposition, the compound proposition "not p1" is represented as ~p1.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 and p2" is represented as p1&p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 or p2" is represented as p1||p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "if p1, then p2" is represented as p1=::>p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 if and only if p2" is represented as p1=p2.
A single proposition and proposition constants can be called a formula.
Formulas are represented using F1, F2, ..., Fn.
If F1 is a formula, then ~F1 is also a formula.
If F1 and F2 are formulas, then F1&F2, F1||F2, F1=::>F2, F1=F2 are also formulas.
Level A Formula: The most basic proposition unit, without logical connectives or nested structures.
Level B Formula: A formula containing one logical connective, and the connected two propositions are both Level A formulas.For example, p1.
Level C Formula: A formula containing nested logical connectives and at least one Level B formula.For example, ~p1.
Other levels of logic follow by analogy; when higher than Level Z, they are classified as Z+n (n≥1).For example, ~(~p1).
True assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as ✓, indicating that p1 is true.
False assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as x, indicating that p1 is false.
True assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|x,✓|✓|x are true assignments of the formula.
False assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|✓,x|✓|✓ are false assignments of the formula.
For p1=::>p2, only ✓|x is a false assignment of the formula.
A formula that is true under all assignments is called a Truth Formula.
A formula that is false under all assignments is called a Falsehood Formula.
Recursive definition of formulas: Any formula containing nested logical connectives can be decomposed recursively to obtain its subformulas and their logical connective structures.
Priority of logical connectives: The priority of logical connectives from high to low is as follows: ~ (not), & (and), || (or), =::> (if...then), = (if and only if).
Without parentheses, operations are performed according to priority.
Equivalence of formulas: Two formulas are equivalent if they have the same truth value under all assignments.
Equivalent formulas can be interchanged.
Simplification of formulas: Formulas can be simplified through logical rules to obtain a more concise form without changing the truth value of the formula.

If F1 is a formula, then ~F1 is also a formula.
If F1 and F2 are formulas, then F1&F2, F1||F2, F1=::>F2, F1=F2 are also formulas.
Level A Formula: The most basic proposition unit, without logical connectives or nested structures.
Level B Formula: A formula containing one logical connective, and the connected two propositions are both Level A formulas.For example, p1.
Level C Formula: A formula containing nested logical connectives and at least one Level B formula.For example, ~p1.
Other levels of logic follow by analogy; when higher than Level Z, they are classified as Z+n (n≥1).For example, ~(~p1).
True assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as ✓, indicating that p1 is true.
False assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as x, indicating that p1 is false.
True assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|x,✓|✓|x are true assignments of the formula.
False assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|✓,x|✓|✓ are false assignments of the formula.
For p1=::>p2, only ✓|x is a false assignment of the formula.
A formula that is true under all assignments is called a Truth Formula.
A formula that is false under all assignments is called a Falsehood Formula.
Recursive definition of formulas: Any formula containing nested logical connectives can be decomposed recursively to obtain its subformulas and their logical connective structures.
Priority of logical connectives: The priority of logical connectives from high to low is as follows: ~ (not), & (and), || (or), =::> (if...then), = (if and only if).
Without parentheses, operations are performed according to priority.
Equivalence of formulas: Two formulas are equivalent if they have the same truth value under all assignments.
Equivalent formulas can be interchanged.
Simplification of formulas: Formulas can be simplified through logical rules to obtain a more concise form without changing the truth value of the formula.

### Question:
Given:
p1: Blue is a common color.
p2: Yellow is a common color.
p3: \sqrt{3}  is irrational.
p4: 5 is irrational.

Symbolize the following propositions:
(1) Blue and yellow are both common colors.
(2) Either \sqrt{3} or 5 is irrational.
(3) Exactly one of \sqrt{3} and 5 is irrational.

Specify that only &,||,~ can be used for this question.
Please format your answers as [[ ];[ ];[ ]], where each bracketed section contains the corresponding logical expression for each proposition.

### Answer:
response:
Using the given symbols and logical connectives &, ||, ~, we can represent the propositions as follows:

(1) Blue and yellow are both common colors can be represented using "and" as p1 & p2.
(2) Either \sqrt{3} or 5 is irrational can be represented using "or" as p3 || p4.
(3) Exactly one of \sqrt{3} and 5 is irrational means that either \sqrt{3} is irrational and 5 is rational, or \sqrt{3} is rational and 5 is irrational. This can be represented as (p3 & ~p4) || (~p3 & p4).

Formating the answer as requested, the output is:

[[p1&p2];[p3||p4];[(p3&~p4)||(~~p3&p4)]]

Note: Since ~~p3 is equivalent to p3, it can be simplified to [[p1&p2];[p3||p4];[(p3&~p4)||(~p3&p4)]], but the original request to strictly follow the format specified in the question will keep it as is. However, for logical correctness and simplicity, it's often beneficial to simplify to [[p1&p2];[p3||p4];[(p3&~p4)||(~p3&p4)]].

### Question:
Given:
p1: 4 is even.
p2: 5 is odd.

Symbolize the following propositions:
(1) Only if 4 is even, 5 is odd.
(2) If 4 is even, then 5 is even.
(3) Only 4 being even makes 5 even.
(4) 4 is even if and only if 5 is odd.
Please format your answers as [[ ];[ ];[ ];[ ]], where each bracketed section contains the corresponding logical expression for each proposition.

### Answer:
response:
Based on the given propositions and the logic rules provided, we can symbolize the given statements as follows:

(1) Only if 4 is even, 5 is odd.
This translates to: If 5 is odd, then 4 is even. Using p1 and p2 as defined, this is symbolized as p2=::>p1.

(2) If 4 is even, then 5 is even.
Since we have defined p1 as "4 is even" and p2 as "5 is odd," to express "5 is even," we need to negate p2 (because if 5 is not odd, it is even; thus, the negation of "5 is odd" expresses "5 is even"). The expression "If 4 is even, then 5 is even" can be written as p1=::>~p2.

(3) Only 4 being even makes 5 even.
This means that 4 being even is a necessary condition for 5 to be even. This is another way of stating that if 5 is even, then 4 must be even; using p1 for "4 is even" and ~p2 for "5 is even" (since 5 not being odd means it is even), the logical expression for this is ~p2=::>p1.

(4) 4 is even if and only if 5 is odd.
This is a direct statement of equivalence between the conditions, symbolized as p1=p2.

Thus, the answers in the requested format are:

[[p2=::>p1];[p1=::>~p2];[~p2=::>p1];[p1=p2]]

### Question:
Find the truth values and falsity values of the following formulas.
(1) ~(p1&p2&~p3)
(2) (~p1&p2)=::>(p1=p3)
The answer format  is [[T:...;F:...];[T:...;F:...]]. If there are multiple values in T(F), they should be separated by commas (,).For example [[T:✓|✓|✓;F:x|x|x];[T:x|x|x,x|x|✓;F:✓|✓|✓]]

### Answer:
response:
To answer the question, we need to evaluate the truth values and falsity values of each formula under all possible assignments of p1, p2, and p3. Each proposition (p1, p2, p3) can be either true (✓) or false (x). We will evaluate each formula accordingly.

### Evaluating Formula (1): ~(p1&p2&~p3)

Let's consider all combinations of truth values for p1, p2, and p3:
- If p1, p2, and p3 are all true (✓|✓|✓), then p1&p2&~p3 evaluates to x since ~p3 becomes false. Hence, ~(p1&p2&~p3) = ~(✓&✓&x) = ~(x) = ✓.
- If p1 is true (✓) and only p2 is false (x|✓|✓), then p1&p2&~p3 is false, so the formula evaluates to true.
- If p1 is true (✓) and p2 is false (x|✓|✓), and p3 is false (✓|x|x), then p1&p2&~p3 is false, so the formula evaluates to true.
- ... and so on for all combinations.

The truth table systematically covering all cases will show that the only time the formula evaluates to false (x) is when p1, p2 are true, and p3 is false (✓|✓|x). For all other combinations, ~(p1&p2&~p3) is true.

Thus, T: (All combinations except ✓|✓|x) and F: (✓|✓|x).

### Evaluating Formula (2): (~p1&p2)=::>(p1=p3)

To evaluate this, we need to identify when the left side (~p1&p2) implies the right side (p1=p3).
- If ~p1&p2 is false (✓|x or x|x), regardless of the value of p1=p3, the entire formula is true.
- If ~p1&p2 is true (✓), then p1 must be false and p2 must be true. For (~p1&p2)=::>(p1=p3) to be false, p1 must equal p3, which in this case means p2 must equate (false=✓, a contradiction).

Thus, the formula (~p1&p2)=::>(p1=p3) evaluates to false (x) only when p1 and p3 are both true (✓) and p2 is true (✓|✓|✓).

Hence, T: (All cases except ✓|✓|✓) and F: (✓|✓|✓).

### Final Answer

The truth values and falsity values of the given formulas are as follows:

- For formula (1): ~(p1&p2&~p3)
  - [[T:✓|x|x, x|x|✓, x|✓|✓, x|✓|x, ✓|✓|x, x|x|x, x|x|✓]; [F:✓|✓|x]]
- For formula (2): (~p1&p2)=::>(p1=p3)
  - [[T:x|x|x, x|x|✓, ✓|x|x, x|✓|x, ✓|x|✓, x|✓|✓]; [F:✓|✓|✓]]

Putting this in the specified format, the answer is:

[[T:✓|x|x,x|x|✓,x|✓|✓,x|✓|x,✓|✓|x,x|x|x,x|x|✓;T:x|x|x,x|x|✓,✓|x|x,x|✓|x,✓|x|✓,x|✓|✓];[F:✓|✓|x;F:✓|✓|✓]]

question:
Find the falsity values of the following formulas:
(1)~(~p1&p2)||~p3
(2)(~p2||p3)&(p1=::>p2)
(3)(p1=::>p2)&(~(p1&p3)||p1)

Let p1 be a proposition, the compound proposition "not p1" is represented as ~p1.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 and p2" is represented as p1&p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 or p2" is represented as p1||p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "if p1, then p2" is represented as p1=::>p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 if and only if p2" is represented as p1=p2.
A single proposition and proposition constants can be called a formula.
Formulas are represented using F1, F2, ..., Fn.
If F1 is a formula, then ~F1 is also a formula.
If F1 and F2 are formulas, then F1&F2, F1||F2, F1=::>F2, F1=F2 are also formulas.
Level A Formula: The most basic proposition unit, without logical connectives or nested structures.
Level B Formula: A formula containing one logical connective, and the connected two propositions are both Level A formulas.For example, p1.
Level C Formula: A formula containing nested logical connectives and at least one Level B formula.For example, ~p1.
Other levels of logic follow by analogy; when higher than Level Z, they are classified as Z+n (n≥1).For example, ~(~p1).
True assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as ✓, indicating that p1 is true.
False assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as x, indicating that p1 is false.
True assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|x,✓|✓|x are true assignments of the formula.
False assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|✓,x|✓|✓ are false assignments of the formula.
For p1=::>p2, only ✓|x is a false assignment of the formula.
A formula that is true under all assignments is called a Truth Formula.
A formula that is false under all assignments is called a Falsehood Formula.
Recursive definition of formulas: Any formula containing nested logical connectives can be decomposed recursively to obtain its subformulas and their logical connective structures.
Priority of logical connectives: The priority of logical connectives from high to low is as follows: ~ (not), & (and), || (or), =::> (if...then), = (if and only if).
Without parentheses, operations are performed according to priority.
Equivalence of formulas: Two formulas are equivalent if they have the same truth value under all assignments.
Equivalent formulas can be interchanged.
Simplification of formulas: Formulas can be simplified through logical rules to obtain a more concise form without changing the truth value of the formula.

### Question:
Find the falsity values of the following formulas:
(1)~(~p1&p2)||~p3
(2)(~p2||p3)&(p1=::>p2)
(3)(p1=::>p2)&(~(p1&p3)||p1)
The answer format is [[F:...];[F:...];[F:...]].If there are multiple values in F, they should be separated by commas (,).For example [[F:x|x|x];[F:✓|✓|✓];[F:x|x|x,✓|✓|✓]]

### Answer:
response:
To solve for the falsity values of the given formulas, we will analyze each formula under different proposition assignments (✓ and x) and determine when each formula is false.

### Formula (1): ~(~p1&p2)||~p3
This formula can be broken down into parts to analyze its falsity values.

- Let's start with the right-hand side (~p3). The value of ~p3 will be x if p3 is ✓.
- Now consider the left-hand side (~(~p1&p2)):
  - For ~(~p1&p2) to be false, (~p1&p2) must be true.
  - So, for (~p1&p2) to be true, p2 must be ✓, and ~p1 must be true, meaning p1 is x.
  
- For the entire formula to be false, both parts must be false at the same time:
  - ~(~p1&p2) is false if ~p1&p2 is true, which happens when p1 is x and p2 is ✓.
  - ~p3 is x when p3 is ✓.
  
Therefore, the falsity values for formula (1) are when p1 is x, p2 is ✓, and p3 is ✓:
F: x|✓|✓

### Formula (2): (~p2||p3)&(p1=::>p2)
- For &(and) to be false, at least one side must be false.
- Consider the first part (~p2||p3):
  - This part will be false if ~p2 is x and p3 is x, implying p2 is ✓ and p3 is x.
  
- Consider the second part (p1=::>p2):
  - This part is false only when p1 is ✓ and p2 is x.
  
Combining both sides, both cannot simultaneously make the overall formula false. However, only when p1 is ✓, p2 is x, and p3 can be anything (but ideally, checking with p3=x to minimize redundancy since ~p2||p3 can be false):
F: ✓|x|x

### Formula (3): (p1=::>p2)&(~(p1&p3)||p1)
- Breaking it down:
  - The first part (p1=::>p2) is false if p1 is ✓ and p2 is x.
  - The second part (~(p1&p3)||p1):
    - ~(p1&p3) is false if (p1&p3) is true, so both p1 and p3 are ✓.
    - p1 being ✓ makes the whole (~p1&p3) true if p3 is ✓ and negated effectively false.
    - With (p1 & p3) being true, the second part would be true when p1 & p3 are simultaneously true.
  
The overall formula (3) is false when p1 is ✓, p2 is x, and p3 is ✓:
F: ✓|x|✓

### Final Answer:
The falsity values for the given formulas in the specified format are:
[[F:x|✓|✓];[F:✓|x|x];[F:✓|x|✓]].

### Question:
Please determine the level of the formula (~(p1=::>~p2))&((p3||p4)=~p1). 
The answer should be given as a single letter from A to Z, or Z+n (where n is a number greater than or equal to 1).The answer format should be like [[A]].

### Answer:
response:
To determine the level of the formula given by (~(p1=::>~p2))&((p3||p4)=~p1), we need to analyze the structure of the compound formula recursively.

1. The innermost parts of the formula are:
    - p1=::>~p2 is a Level B formula because it's connected by =::> and contains two Level A formulas.
    - p3||p4 is also a Level B formula as it's connected by || and contains two Level A formulas.
    - ~p1, ~p2, and ~p4 are Level C formulas because they are negations of Level A formulas.
2. The formulas ~(p1=::>~p2) and (p3||p4)=~p1 are composed of higher-level structures and require an additional step of analysis:
    - ~(p1=::>~p2) has the negation operator ~ applied to a Level B formula, making it a Level C formula.
    - (p3||p4)=~p1 has =::> connecting a Level B formula (p3||p4) with a Level C formula (~p1), making it a Level C formula.
3. Finally, the entire formula (~(p1=::>~p2))&((p3||p4)=~p1) contains two Level C formulas connected by the & operator, making it a Level C formula.

However, the complexity introduced by the nested structures and the usage of multiple connectives suggests that this formula doesn't simply qualify as a Level C but requires a higher categorization based on the nestedness and combination of logical connectives.

Given the defined levels, when formulas exceed Level Z, they are classified as Z+n with n≥1, where n indicates the additional layer of nesting above Level Z. Thus, this formula, due to the nested logical connectives and combined higher-level connectives, qualifies as being beyond Level Z.

Therefore, the level of the formula is:

[[Z+1]]

### Answer:
response:
To transform the expression \((p > q) > r\) into its equivalent form without using the implication operator `>`, we need to apply the equivalence rule (10), which states that \(A > B ::=:: !A | B\).

1. Identify the first implication: \(p > q\).
   - According to equivalence (10), \(p > q\) can be replaced with \(!p | q\).

2. Substitute \(!p | q\) for \(p > q\) into the original expression.
   - The expression now is \((!p | q) > r\).

3. Apply equivalence (10) again on the new implication:
   - Replace \((!p | q) > r\) with \(!(!p | q) | r\).

4. Simplify \(!(!p | q)\) using De Morgan's law (or Basic Equivalence (6)):
   - By equivalence (6), \(!(A | B) ::=:: !A & !B\), we have \(!(!p | q) ::=:: !!p & !q\).
   - Since \(!\(!p\)\) is equivalent to \(p\), this reduces to \(p & !q\).

5. Combine the simplified form with `| r`:
   - The expression simplifies to \((p & !q) | r\).

Hence, the equivalent expression obtained by removing all occurrences of `>` in \((p > q) > r\) is \((p & !q) | r\).

### Answer:

To answer the question, we need to determine if the provided equivalences hold true according to the provided basic equivalences.

### For (1) p ::=:: (p & q) | (p & !q)

### Question:

First person: Professor Wang is not from Suzhou, he is from Shanghai.
Second person: Professor Wang is not from Shanghai, he is from Suzhou.
Third person: Professor Wang is neither from Shanghai nor from Hangzhou.

After hearing these judgments, Professor Wang chuckled and remarked, "One of you got everything right, one got half right, and one got everything wrong."
Let p denote "Professor Wang is from Suzhou," 
q denote "Professor Wang is from Shanghai," 
and r denote "Professor Wang is from Hangzhou." 
Exactly one of p,q,r is true, and the other two are false.
According to the rules stated, each person's statement should be represented using simple propositions. So, what would the statements of First person, Second person, and Third person be represented as?
Answers are formatted as [[ ];[ ];[ ]]. Each bracketed section should contain the corresponding logical expression for each individual statement.

### Answer:
response:
To represent the statements of the first, second, and third persons according to the given propositions (p for Suzhou, q for Shanghai, and r for Hangzhou), we can symbolize each statement according to the logic symbols provided.

1. First person: "Professor Wang is not from Suzhou, he is from Shanghai."
   - Symbolically, this is represented as `!p & q`.

2. Second person: "Professor Wang is not from Shanghai, he is from Suzhou."
   - Symbolically, this is represented as `!q & p`.

3. Third person: "Professor Wang is neither from Shanghai nor from Hangzhou."
   - Since exactly one among `p, q, r` is true, and according to the statement the person is claiming that it is neither `q` nor `r` (Shanghai nor Hangzhou). Therefore, this is falsely claiming that Professor Wang is from Suzhou because exactly one of the propositions is true, not both `q` and `r` being false.
   - Symbolically, this is represented as `!q & !r`.

However, the third statement is tricky because it involves the condition that exactly one of `p, q, r` is true. Hence, a fuller consideration of the third statement in the context of one of them being true will convert to `p | r`, thus `p` stands for the correct place if `q` and `r` are false. Thus, symbolization in terms of the professor's exact position being considered true would be the complete truth condition, considering `p | q | r` with exactly one being true - so the negative (`!q & !r`) portion simplifies to `p`, given the unique true proposition.

Given that the third statement actually negates possibilities of `q` and `r` being true, the symbolic representation for the third statement that one is true fits correctly if directly considered.

Thus, the final representation should be adjusted to properly reflect the truth constraint condition:

1. First person: `!p & q`.
2. Second person: `!q & p`.
3. Third person based on the true proposition condition, `p | r` valid stating `!q & !r` by negation and condition yielding directly `p`.

Thus, the logical expressions are properly represented as `[!p & q; !q & p; !q & !r]`.

But based on simple proposition directly true condition understanding:
- First person's statement truth condition under general is `[!p & q]`.
- Second person's statement truth condition under general is `[!q & p]`.
- Third person's proper derivation in context is directly `[p]` considering true only condition.

Given this observed format and context, the괄호를 제거하고 삼단논리를 명확하게 표현하자. 첫번째, 두번째, 세번째 사람의 말을 나타내는 논리식은 각각 다음과 같습니다:

- 첫번째 사람: "왕 교수는 수창에서 오지 않았고, 상하이에서 왔다."는 `!p & q`로 나타낼 수 있습니다.
- 두번째 사람: "왕 교수는 상하이에서 오지 않았고, 수창에서 왔다."는 `!q & p`로 나타낼 수 있습니다.
- 세번째 사람: "왕 교수는 상하이도 안가고 항주도 안갔다."는 `!q & !r`로 나타내지만, 이는 왕 교수가 실제로 수창 출신이라는 것이 의미하는 것이므로, 단순히 `p`로 표기할 수 있습니다.

### Question:
During a break at a seminar, three attendees tried to determine where Professor Wang is from based on his accent. Their statements were as follows:

Person A: Professor Wang is not from Suzhou, he is from Shanghai.
Person B: Professor Wang is not from Shanghai, he is from Suzhou.
Person C: Professor Wang is neither from Shanghai nor from Hangzhou.

After hearing these judgments, Professor Wang chuckled and remarked, "One of you got everything right, one got half right, and one got everything wrong."

Let p denote "Professor Wang is from Suzhou," 
q denote "Professor Wang is from Shanghai," 
and r denote "Professor Wang is from Hangzhou." 

Exactly one of p,q,r is true, and the other two are false.
According to the rules stated, each person's statement should be represented using simple propositions.
Represent each person's statement:
Person A:!p&q
Person B:p&!q
Person C:!q&!r

Define the following logical expressions for Person A:
B1=!p&q (Person A's statements are entirely correct).
B2=(!p&!q)|(p&q) (Person A's  statements are partially correct).
B3=p&!q (Person A's statements are entirely incorrect).

Similarly, define the analogous expressions for Person B:
C1 (Person B's statements are entirely correct).
C2 (Person B's  statements are partially correct).
C3 (Person B's statements are entirely incorrect).

And for Person C:
D1 (Person C's statements are entirely correct).
D2 (Person C's  statements are partially correct).
D3 (Person C's statements are entirely incorrect).

Please provide the corresponding logical expressions. The answer format should be:
[[C1=...];[C2=...];[C3=...];[D1=...];[D2=...];[D3=...]].

### Answer:
response:
To define the logical expressions for the statements made by Person B and Person C, and to ensure that exactly one of p, q, r is true (and the other two are false), we need to follow the given logical rules and format. Using the given propositions as well as the correct representations, we can derive the expressions for which each individual's claims could correspond to getting everything right, half right, or everything wrong. 

Given p, q, and r, we know that one of the following must be true: p or q or r, but only one of these at any given time must be true. From the statements made, let's define the logical expressions for Person B and Person C based on their statements:

Person B: p & !q

For Person B getting it 'entirely correct':
- C1 would mean that all of B's statements (p & !q) are true, implying Professor Wang is from Suzhou and not from Shanghai. 
- C1 ::=:: p & !q

For Person B getting it 'partially correct':
- C2 would mean that either A part of B's statement is true and the other part is false. However, since the given rule for partial correctness rather defines a complete lie or truth but not a mix, where only a part is correct, we redefine this context as: at least one of (p & q) or (!p & !q) but not both. 
- C2 ::=:: (p & !q) | (!p & q)

For Person B getting it 'entirely incorrect':
- C3 would mean that both of B's statements (p & !q) are false.
- C3 ::=:: !p | q

We can apply a similar logic sequence to establish Person C's statements:

Person C: !q & !r

For Person C getting it 'entirely correct':
- D1 would mean that all of C's statements (!q & !r) are true, implying Professor Wang is not from Shanghai and not from Hangzhou.
- D1 ::=:: !q & !r & p (since only p is true)

For Person C getting it 'partially correct':
- D2 would be derived from the fact that Professor Wang is neither from q nor from r, but we need to ensure that if one part is true, the other parts are wrong.
- D2 ::=:: (!q & r) | (q & !r)

For Person C getting it 'entirely incorrect':
- D3 would mean that both of C's statements are false.
- D3 ::=:: q | r

Thus, combining all these definitions as per the required format, the final logical expressions become:

[[C1=p&!q];[C2=(p&!q)|(!p&q)];[C3=!p|q];[D1=!q&!r&p];[D2=(!q&r)|(q&!r)];[D3=q|r]]

This representation adheres to the given rules of logical equivalences, ensuring the statements can be correctly evaluated according to the judgments made by Professor Wang.

    (4) (A | B) | C ::=:: A | (B | C), (A & B) & C ::=:: A & (B & C)

    (7) A | (A & B) ::=:: A, A & (A | B) ::=:: A
    (8) A | !A ::=:: 1

    (16) A ⇓ B ::=:: !A & !B
3. Equivalence Calculation Rules:

4. Truth Value Judgment Steps:
    - Define the practical problem to be judged as simple propositions and symbolize them.
    - Use simple propositions to express the formula based on each person's description.
    - Combine the information of who is true and who is false to write the final logical expression.
    - Use the above equivalences to derive and judge the truth of the expression.

### Question:
During a break at a seminar, three attendees tried to determine where Professor Wang is from based on his accent. Their statements were as follows:

Person A: Professor Wang is not from Suzhou, he is from Shanghai.
Person B: Professor Wang is not from Shanghai, he is from Suzhou.
Person C: Professor Wang is neither from Shanghai nor from Hangzhou.

After hearing these judgments, Professor Wang chuckled and remarked, "One of you got everything right, one got half right, and one got everything wrong."
Let p denote "Professor Wang is from Suzhou,"
q denote "Professor Wang is from Shanghai,"
and r denote "Professor Wang is from Hangzhou."

Exactly one of p,q,r is true, and the other two are false.
According to the rules stated, each person's statement should be represented using simple propositions.
Represent each person's statement:
Person A:!p&q
Person B:p&!q
Person C:!q&!r

Define the following logical expressions for Person A:

B1=!p&q (Person A's statements are entirely correct).
B2=(!p&!q)|(p&q) (Person A's  statements are partially correct).
B3=p&!q (Person A's statements are entirely incorrect).

Similarly, define the analogous expressions for Person B:
C1=p&!q.(Person B's statements are entirely correct).
C2=(p & q) | (!p & !q).(Person B's  statements are partially correct).
C3=!p&q.(Person B's statements are entirely incorrect).

And for Person C:
D1=!q&!r.(Person C's statements are entirely correct).
D2=(!q&r)|(q&!r).(Person C's  statements are partially correct).
D3=q&r.(Person C's statements are entirely incorrect).

According to Professor Wang's remarks, the final logical expression
E=(B1&C2&D3)|(B1&C3&D2)|(B2&C1&D3)|(B2&C3&D1)|(B3&C1&D2)|(B3&C2&D1)

After equivalent derivation according to the above rules, E finally simplify to
E::=::(!p&q&!r)|(p&!q&r).

Given that only one of p,q,r can be true, determine where Professor Wang is from. Who got everything right? Who got half right? Who got everything wrong?
Each choice should be selected from the three options provided.
Please provide the corresponding answers. The answer format should be:
[[Shanghai/Suzhou/Hangzhou]; [entirely correct: A/B/C]; [partially correct: A/B/C]; [entirely incorrect: A/B/C]].

### Answer:
response:
To solve this problem, we need to identify which of the three statements (from Person A, Person B, or Person C) correspond to the completely correct, partially correct, and entirely incorrect categories based on the provided logical expression. According to the final simplified logical expression,

\[ E ::=:: (!p \& q \& !r) | (p \& !q \& r) \]

we can derive the truth value of statements from p, q, and r given the condition that exactly one of them is true (and we have a binary choice for the true statement).

1. **Case 1:** \( !p \& q \& !r \)
   - This case is true if Professor Wang is from Shanghai (\(q\)) and not from Suzhou (\(p\)) and not from Hangzhou (\(r\)).
   - In this condition, Person A's statement `(!p & q)` is entirely correct, Person B's statement `(p & !q)` is entirely incorrect, and Person C's statement `(!q & !r)` is partially correct.
   - Therefore, in this case: **[Shanghai]; [entirely correct: A]; [partially correct: C]; [entirely incorrect: B]**.

2. **Case 2:** \( p \& !q \& r \)
   - This case results in Professor Wang being from Hangzhou (\(r\)), not from Suzhou (\(p\)), and not from Shanghai (\(q\)).
   - In this condition, Person C's statement `(!q & !r)` is entirely incorrect, Person B's statement `(p & !q)` is partially correct, and Person A's statement `(!p & q)` is entirely incorrect.
   - Therefore, in this case: **[Hangzhou]; [entirely incorrect: A]; [partially correct: B]; [entirely incorrect: C]**, which is logically incorrect as per the formulated conditions and Professor's remark. Thus, option (2) can be invalidated considering only one person is entirely incorrect and one is partly incorrect.

Given these two case analyses, only Case 1 satisfies the conditions Professor Wang gave that "one of you got everything right, one got half right, and one got everything wrong."

Thus, the chosen answer format is:

**[[Shanghai]; [entirely correct: A]; [partially correct: C]; [entirely incorrect: B]]**.

title: Disjunctive Normal Form and Conjunctive Normal Form
rule_content:
In a simple conjunctive form (simple disjunctive form) containing n propositional variables, if each propositional variable and its negation appear exactly once, and the propositional variables or their negations are arranged in ascending order of subscripts or in lexicographical order, such a simple conjunctive form (simple disjunctive form) is called a paired conjunctive term (paired disjunctive term).
If the true assignment of a paired conjunctive term corresponds to a binary number equal to hexadecimal number i, this paired conjunctive term is denoted as mi (lowercase m). For example, the true assignment of p∧q is 11, and the binary number is 11, corresponding to hexadecimal number 3, denoted as m3.
If the false assignment of a paired disjunctive term corresponds to a binary number equal to hexadecimal number i, this paired disjunctive term is denoted as Mi (uppercase M). For example, the false assignment of ¬p∨¬q∨¬r is 111, and the binary number is 111, corresponding to hexadecimal number 7, denoted as M7.
The disjunctive normal form (conjunctive normal form) consisting of all paired conjunctive terms (paired disjunctive terms) is called the principal disjunctive normal form (principal conjunctive normal form).
Given a formula A containing n propositional variables:
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes all 2^n paired conjunctive terms, A is a tautology.
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes no paired conjunctive terms, A is a contradiction.
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes m0, A is a basic formula.
- If the indices i of the paired conjunctive terms included in the principal disjunctive normal form of A are all even, A is an all-even formula.
- If the indices i of the paired conjunctive terms included in the principal disjunctive normal form of A are all odd, A is an all-odd formula.

A. Tautology B. Contradiction C. Basic Form D. All-Even Form E. All-Odd Form F. None of the Above

Answer format: [[denoted expression];[options]]

### Answer:
response:
### Step-by-step Solution:

To translate and analyze the given logic formula into the requested format, let's follow the process step by step:

1. **Rules Clarification:** Understand the rules for denoting the formula, specifically how to translate true assignments into hexadecimal values.
2. **True Assignment Analysis:** Convert the disjunctive normal form (DNF) of the given formula into the hexadecimal notation for the true assignments.
3. **Characterization Based on Denoted Form:** Determine the exact category the formula belongs to according to the given rules.

### Step 1: Translate True Assignments to Hexadecimal Equivalents

The given DNF:
\[ (\neg p \land \neg q \land r) \lor (\neg p \land q \land \neg r) \lor (p \land \neg q \land r) \]

Each clause corresponds to a true assignment:
- \(\neg p \land \neg q \land r\): True when p=0, q=0, r=1 (binary 001), hexadecimal: 1
- \(\neg p \land q \land \neg r\): True when p=0, q=1, r=0 (binary 010), hexadecimal: 2
- \(p \land \neg q \land r\): True when p=1, q=0, r=1 (binary 101), hexadecimal: 5

Therefore, the principal disjunctive normal form (PDNF) can be denoted as:

- If all the indices are even: All-Even Form
- If all the indices are odd: All-Odd Form

- If no paired conjunctive terms are included: Contradiction

Given:

- The given expression does not include \(m0\).
- It includes less than all (2^3 = 8) possible terms since there are only 3 out of 8 possible true assignments present.

Thus, the formula is not a tautology, contradictation, and does not perfectly fit into "all-even" or "all-odd" categories.

Therefore:
\[ \text{Denoted expression: } m1 \lor m2 \lor m5 \]
\[ \text{The formula belongs to option: } F \text{ (None of the Above)} \]

### Final Answer:
[[m1; m2; m5]; F]

title: Resolution
rule_content:
Literal: A propositional variable and its negation are collectively referred to as literals.

Complement: If L is a literal, then the complement of L is denoted as L’. If L = p, then L’ = ¬p; if L = ¬p, then L’ = p.

Resolution: Suppose simple disjunctive clause C1 = C3 ∨ L, C2 = C4 ∨ L’, then C1 and C2 can be resolved, and it is defined that dispel(C1, C2) = C3 ∨ C4. If it is empty, then dispel(C1, C2) = 0.

Resolution Algorithm: The steps to determine if a conjunctive normal form has a satisfying assignment are as follows:
1. Input: Conjunctive normal form S.
2. Output: If S has a satisfying assignment, output “Plausible”; otherwise, output “Implausible”.
3. Steps:
    1. Initialization:
        - Let S0 and S2 be empty sets.
        - Let S1 be the set of all simple disjunctive clauses in S.
    2. Resolve clauses in S0 and S1:
        - For each simple disjunctive clause C1 in S0 and each simple disjunctive clause C2 in S1:
            - If C1 and C2 can be resolved, calculate C = dispel(C1, C2).
            - If C = 0, output “Implausible” and terminate the calculation.
            - If neither S0 nor S1 contains C, add C to S2.
    3. Resolve clauses in S1:
        - For each pair of clauses C1 and C2 in S1:
            - If C1 and C2 can be resolved, calculate C = dispel(C1, C2).
            - If C = 0, output “Implausible” and terminate the calculation.
            - If neither S0 nor S1 contains C, add C to S2.
    4. Check S2:
        - If S2 contains no elements, output “Plausible” and terminate the calculation.
        - Otherwise, add S1 to S0, set S1 to S2, clear S2, and return to step b.

response:
Given C1 = ¬p ∨ q ∨ r and C2 = p ∨ ¬r ∨ ¬s, we aim to calculate dispel(C1, C2).

Taking p and ¬p:
- Resolving C1 and C2 on ¬p and p yields q ∨ r ∨ ¬r ∨ ¬s.
Since r ∨ ¬r forms a tautology, it can be simplified out, leaving q ∨ ¬s.

Taking r and ¬r:
- Resolving C1 and C2 on r and ¬r yields ¬p ∨ q ∨ p ∨ ¬s.
Since ¬p ∨ p forms a tautology, it simplifies to q ∨ ¬s.

Thus, we see that the resolution of C1 and C2 on both p/¬p and r/¬r yields the same result:
dispel(C1, C2) = [q ∨ ¬s]

Therefore, the answer in the requested format is:
[q ∨ ¬s]

### Question:
Regarding (¬p ∨ q)∧(p ∨ q) ∧ (q), 
what are S0, S1, and S2 before starting the resolution algorithm, 
and why is S2 after the first loop iteration? 
Provide the answers in the format [[];[];[];[]],
where sets are represented using {}, 
and an empty set is denoted by ∅.

### Answer:
response:
Let's break down the answer according to the given steps and format requirements:

### Initial Step

Given formula in conjunctive normal form (CNF): S = (¬p ∨ q) ∧ (p ∨ q) ∧ (q)

We convert this formula into its constituent clauses:

1. ¬p ∨ q
2. p ∨ q
3. q (can be written as q ∨ ∅)

#### Step 1: Initialization

- S0 (the set of resolved clauses) = ∅
- S1 (the current set of simple disjunctive clauses) = {¬p ∨ q, p ∨ q, q}
- S2 (the set of newly generated clauses) = ∅

### Format Representation Before Starting the Resolution Algorithm
At the beginning of the resolution process, S0, S1, and S2 are:

```
[∅;{¬p ∨ q, p ∨ q, q};∅]
```

### Iterative Resolution Logic

Now let's apply the resolution rules step by step as per the instructions:

1. **Step b - Resolve Between S0 and S1:**

Since S0 is currently ∅, step b won't add any clauses to S2 initially.

2. **Step 3 - Resolve Between S1 and S1:**

- Resolving (¬p ∨ q) and (p ∨ q) using the resolution rule:
  - L = p, L' = ¬p.
  - dispel(C1, C2) = (¬p ∨ q) ∨ (p ∨ q) = q ∨ q,
  which simplifies to q, yielding a clause not new to S1.
  
  Since the outcome q is already present in S1, no new clause is generated here.

- Resolving (¬p ∨ q) and (q):
  - L = ¬p, L' does not exist independently, so this cannot resolve here.

- Resolving (p ∨ q) and (q):
  - L = p, L' does not exist independently, so this cannot resolve here.

Since only existing clauses are produced, no new clauses are generated in S2 at this stage.

3. **Check S2 for Empty Set:**

Since S2 is still ∅, we proceed to the next iteration.

### Update and Repeat

In the next iteration:

- S2 should be checked for addition to S0 and S1. Given S2 remains ∅, and there are no newly generated clauses to add to S1.

Since after the first resolution loop iteration, no new clauses have been added to S2 from the application of the resolution rule:

### Format Representation After the First Loop Iteration
Therefore, the contents of S0, S1, S2 after the first loop iteration will also remain unchanged:

```
[∅;{¬p ∨ q, p ∨ q, q};∅]
```

This concludes that during the first resolution iteration, there are no new clauses or conflicts generated, keeping S0, S1, and S2 as initialized.

We check pairs of clauses inside \(S1\) to see if they can be resolved:

1. **Resolving \(C_1\) and \(C_2\):** (potentially resolving \(\{p ∨ q\}, \{p ∨ ¬q\}\))

### Question:
Please provide a simple circuit diagram for a OR gate, 
formatted as [[input, output]; [output when circuit is powered, output when circuit is not powered]; ...].

### Answer:
response:
A standard OR gate behaves such that the output is powered ("+") if at least one of its inputs is powered ("+"), and it is not powered ("-") only if all of its inputs are not powered ("-"). For a single-input OR gate, the output would trivially be the same as the input. However, for a two-input OR gate, the operation can be visualized as follows:

- If I1 is powered ("+") and I2 is powered ("+"), then O will be powered ("+").
- If I1 is powered ("+") and I2 is not powered ("-"), then O will be powered ("+").
- If I1 is not powered ("-") and I2 is powered ("+"), then O will be powered ("+").
- If I1 is not powered ("-") and I2 is not powered ("-"), then O will be not powered ("-").

Thus, the circuit diagram for a two-input OR gate can be formatted as:

```
[[I1, I2, O]; ["+", "+", "+"]; ["+", "-", "+"]; ["-", "+", "+"]; ["-", "-", "-"]]
```

This table represents the behavior of an OR gate with two inputs, showing the output state for every combination of input states.

### Question:
What is the simple circuit diagram corresponding to the logical expression ¬(p∧q)?
 Please provide the answer in the format [[input, output]; [output when circuit is powered, output when circuit is not powered]; ...].

### Answer:
response:
The expression ¬(p∧q) involves two inputs, p and q, and a negation operation applied to their conjunction. We can represent the circuit corresponding to this expression by evaluating the truth table for ¬(p∧q).

Here is the truth table for ¬(p∧q):

- When p is + and q is +, (p∧q) is + so ¬(p∧q) is -.
- When p is + and q is -, (p∧q) is - so ¬(p∧q) is +.
- When p is - and q is +, (p∧q) is - so ¬(p∧q) is +.
- When p is - and q is -, (p∧q) is - so ¬(p∧q) is +.

Given the instructions, we map "p" as "I1", "q" as "I2". Therefore, the circuit representation can be provided in the designated format:

```
[[I1, I2, O]; [+, +, -]; [+, -, +]; [-, +, +]; [-, -, +]]
```

However, based on the provided instruction format and what is usually found in this type of question, the output requested expects the resulting truth table in a transformed format, just focusing on varied conditions of inputs:

```
[[+, +, -]; [+, -, +]; [-, +, +]; [-, -, +]]
```

To interpret the notation:
- [[+, +, -]; ...] means when both inputs are powered (+), the output is not powered (-).
- [[+, -, +]; ...] means when the first input (I1) is powered (+) and the second (-), the output is powered (+).
- [[-, +, +]; ...] when the first input is not powered (-) and the second (+), the output is powered (+).
- [[-, -, +]; ...] when neither of the inputs are powered (-), the output is powered (+).

### Question:
What is the simple circuit diagram corresponding to the logical expression (p∧q)∨(p∧r)?
Please provide the answer in the format [[input, output]; [output when circuit is powered, output when circuit is not powered]; ...].

### Answer:
response:
To solve the problem based on the given logic rule, let's first translate the logical expression \((p \wedge q) \vee (p \wedge r)\) into a truth table format and then map the inputs and outputs in the circuit diagram representation.

Given the logical expression \((p \wedge q) \vee (p \wedge r)\):

1. \(p\), \(q\), and \(r\) are the inputs, so we denote them as \(I1\), \(I2\), and \(I3\) respectively.
2. We need to find the output based on the powered state of the inputs (assuming the "+" denotes powered, and "-" denotes not powered).

The truth table for the expression \((p \wedge q) \vee (p \wedge r)\) (with \(p\), \(q\), and \(r\)), is as follows:

1. \(P\) is input 1 (denoted as I1)
2. \(Q\) is input 2 (denoted as I2)
3. \(R\) is input 3 (denoted as I3)

\[
\begin{array}{ccc|c|c}
I1 & I2 & I3 & (I1 \wedge I2) \vee (I1 \wedge I3) = O \\
\hline
- & - & - & - \\
- & - & + & - \\
- & + & - & - \\
- & + & + & - \\
+ & - & - & - \\
+ & - & + & + \\
+ & + & - & + \\
+ & + & + & + \\
\end{array}
\]

Next, the circuit diagram outputs for the respective inputs should be expressed as:

- If all inputs are not powered (each input is "-"):
  \[ [[I1, I2, I3], [-]] \]

- If any one of I2 or I3 are powered when I1 is not powered:
  \[ [I1, I2, I3; -] \]

- If I1 is powered and I2 is not powered and I3 is not powered:
  \[ [[I1, I2, I3], [-]] \]

- If I1 is powered and I2 is powered but I3 is not powered:
  \[ [[I1, I2, I3], [+]] \]

- If I1 is powered and I2 is not powered but I3 is powered:
  \[ [[I1, I2, I3], [+]] \]

- If all three inputs are powered:
  \[ [[I1, I2, I3], [+]] \]

Putting everything in the specified format:
\[ [[[-, -,-], -];
[[-, -,+], -];
[[-, +,-], -];
[[-, +,+], -];
[[+, -,-], -];
[[+, -, +], +];
[[+, +,-], +];
[[+, +,+], +]]
\]

This format gives a clear mapping of every possible input condition to its corresponding output state.

- I1 (which represents p) = "+", i.e., true.
- I2 (which represents q) = "-", i.e., false.
- I3 (which represents r) = "+", i.e., true.

Now, substitute the values into the expression:

1. (p∧q) = (I1∧I2) = (+∧-) = false (since conjunction requires both inputs to be true).
2. (¬p∧r) = (¬I1∧I3) = (¬+∧+) = (-∧+) = false (since negation of true results in false and conjunction requires both inputs to be true).

Since we are dealing with the disjunction (∨) of the two above statements:
- false ∨ false = false.

Therefore, the output is false.

with output O as "+", 
what are the corresponding inputs? 
Please provide multiple inputs that satisfy this condition in the format [[];[];…].

### Answer:
response:
To address this question, we'll analyze the given logical expression \((p∧q)∨(¬p∧(q∨r))\) to determine all sets of input values (p, q, r) that result in "+", given the output \(O\) is "+". We can break this problem down step by step.

1. **Identify the logical expression's components:**
   - \((p∧q)\): This condition will be true if both \(p\) and \(q\) are true.
   - \((q∨r)\): This condition will be true if either \(q\) or \(r\) (or both) is true.
   - \(¬p\): This negates \(p\), meaning if \(p\) is true, \(¬p\) is false and vice versa.

2. **Combine the components using the disjunction (∨):**
   The given expression \((p∧q)∨(¬p∧(q∨r))\) will be true if:
   - \((p∧q)\) is true, or
   - \((¬p∧(q∨r))\) is true.

Since \(O\) is "+", at least one of the above conditions needs to be true.

### Case Analysis:
- For \((p∧q) = +\), both \(p\) and \(q\) must be true.
- For \((¬p∧(q∨r)) = +\), \(p\) must be false (\(¬p\) = +), and \((q∨r)\) must be true (either \(q\) or \(r\) or both must be true).

We can now enumerate all possible combinations that satisfy the output \(O\) = "+":

1. **Case (p = +, q = +, r = [any])**: This satisfies \((p∧q)\).
   - E.g., \([+;+;+]; [+;+;-]\).

2. **Case (p = -, q = +, r = +)**: This satisfies \((¬p∧(q∨r))\).
   - \([-;+;+]\).

3. **Case (p = -, q = +, r = -)**: This also satisfies \((¬p∧(q∨r))\).
   - \([-;+;-]\).

4. **Case (p = -, q = -, r = +)**: This satisfies \((¬p∧(q∨r))\).
   - \([-;-;+]\).

All other combinations would not satisfy the output \(O\) being "+". Therefore, the inputs that satisfy the given logical expression with the output \(O\) as "+" are:

\[ [+;+;+]; [+;+;-]; [-;+;+]; [-;+;-]; [-;-;+] \]

with output O as "-", 
what are the corresponding inputs? 
Please provide multiple inputs that satisfy this condition in the format [[];[];…].

### Answer:
response:
To solve the problem, we need to find the inputs where the given logical expression results in `-` (off or false in logical terms).

The logical expression is: \((p \land q \land \neg r) \lor (\neg p \land q) \lor (p \lor r)\)

We denote `-` as `False` and `+` as `True`. The output \(O = -\) means the entire expression is `False`.

Let's break down the expression into its components in order to understand when this expression equals `False`:

1. \(p \land q \land \neg r\) (all must be true for this to be true)
2. \(\neg p \land q\) (\(q\) must be true and \(p\) must be false)
3. \(p \lor r\) (at least one of them must be true for this to be true)

For \((p \land q \land \neg r) \lor (\neg p \land q) \lor (p \lor r)\) to be `False`, all three component conditions must be `False`:

1. \(p \land q \land \neg r\) must be `False`. This means either \(p\), \(q\), or \(\neg r\) must be `False`.
   - If \(\neg r\) is `False`, then \(r\) must be `True`.
   - In this case, we cannot have both \(p \land q\) both be `True` since then the entire condition would be `True`.
2. \(\neg p \land q\) must be `False`. This means either \(q\) must be `False` or \(p\) must be `True`.
   - If \(p\) is `True`, then automatically \(\neg p\) is `False` and thus the condition is `False`.
3. \(p \lor r\) must be `False`. This means both \(p\) and \(r\) must be `False`.

Given the interdependencies, we find the values of \(p, q, r\) that satisfy all conditions:

1. \(p \lor r\) being `False` means \(p\) and \(r\) both should be `False`.
2. \(\neg p \land q\) being `False` means if \(p\) is `False`, \(q\) can be anything since \(\neg p\) is `True`.
3. \(p \land q \land \neg r\) being `False` is automatically satisfied since \(p\) is `False`.

So, when:
- \(p = -\)
- \(r = -\)
- \(q\) can be either `+` or `-`

We need to list the pairs that satisfy this:

- \(p = True (0); q = True (0); r = True (0)\) - This does not work because \(\neg p \land q\) could be false but failing the main condition.
- \(p = False (0); q = False (0); r = False (0)\)
- \(p = False (0); q = True (0); r = False (0)\)

Accordingly, the required input combinations where the output is `-` are:

\[
[[-, -, -]; [-, +, -]]
\]

So, the final answer in the specified format is:

\[
[[-, -, -]; [-, +, -]]
\]

Logical Connectives:
Conjunction: Use &
Disjunction: Use |
Implication: Use ⇒
Negation: Use ∼

In general, a predicate P with n (n > 1) individual variables is called an n-ary predicate, denoted as P(x1, x2, ..., xn). When n = 1, P(x) denotes the property P; when n ≥ 2, P(x1, x2, ..., xn) denotes the relationship P among x1, x2, ..., xn.

Predicates without individual variables are called 0-ary predicates. For example, F(a), G(a, b), P(a1, ..., an) are all 0-ary predicates.

Let D be the domain of individuals.
"All x in D have property F" is symbolized as AxF(x).
"Some x in D have property F" is symbolized as ExF(x).
"For all x in D, if x has property F, then x has property G" is symbolized as Ax(F(x) ⇒ G(x)).
"Some x in D have both properties F and G" is symbolized as Ex(F(x) & G(x)).

### Question:
Symbolize the following propositions:
(1) All humans have black hair.
(2) Some people have been to the moon.
(3) No one has been to Jupiter.
(4) Students studying in the United States are not necessarily Asian.

Using the universal domain.
Let M(x): x is a human,
(1) Let F(x): x has black hair. Proposition (1) symbolizes as?
(2) Let G(x): x has been to the moon. Proposition (2) symbolizes as?
(3) Let H(x): x has been to Jupiter. Proposition (3) symbolizes as?
(4) Let F(x): x studies in the United States, G(x): x is Asian. Proposition (4) symbolizes as?

Please provide the answers in the format [[];[];[];[]].

### Answer:
response:
Based on the provided predicates and the rules for logical symbolization, here is the representation of each of the given propositions:

(1) All humans have black hair.
Let M(x): x is a human, and F(x): x has black hair.
The proposition "All humans have black hair" is "For all x in D, if x is a human, then x has black hair". In logical symbols, this is represented as:
Ax(M(x) ⇒ F(x))

(2) Some people have been to the moon.
Let G(x): x has been to the moon.
The proposition "Some people have been to the moon" is "There exists some x in D that has been to the moon". In logical symbols, this is represented as:
Ex(G(x))

(3) No one has been to Jupiter.
Let H(x): x has been to Jupiter.
The proposition "No one has been to Jupiter" is equivalent to saying "For all x in D, x has not been to Jupiter". In logical symbols, this is represented as:
Ax(∼H(x))

(4) Students studying in the United States are not necessarily Asian.
Let F(x): x studies in the United States, and G(x): x is Asian.
The proposition "Students studying in the United States are not necessarily Asian" is translated to "For all x in D, if x studies in the United States, then x may or may not be Asian". Since this involves negation of a necessary condition, using implication, we can also say "For all x in D, if x studies in the United States, then it is not necessarily true that x is Asian". This translates into:
Ax(F(x) ⇒ ∼G(x))

However, more accurately symbolizing "not necessarily" (which more closely conveys the proposition's meaning), the correct interpretation should be:
Ax(F(x) ⇒ (G(x) | ∼G(x))) is always true and less accurate to capture the non-necessity directly against one specific outcome, so typically we would simplify that to:
Ax(F(x)) since G(x) or ∼G(x) is always true for any x, but more fitting to the problem's spirit is actually:
Ax(F(x) ⇒ (∼(G(x) & ∼G(x))) can be simplified as Ax(F(x) ⇒ (∼G(x)) directly aiming for denying necessity.

Conclusively,
The answers are presented as follows:
[Ax(M(x) ⇒ F(x)); Ex(G(x)); Ax(∼H(x)); Ax(F(x) ⇒ ∼G(x))]

So, the formatted answer is [[Ax(M(x) ⇒ F(x))]; [Ex(G(x))]; [Ax(∼H(x))]; [Ax(F(x) ⇒ ∼G(x))]].

Given the domain of individuals as the set of natural numbers(N),
F(x): x is even,
G(x): x is prime,

Using 0-ary predicates, symbolize the following propositions:
(1) 2 is an even prime number.
(2) If 2 is prime, then 4 is not prime.
(3) Only 2 is prime, for 6 to be prime.
(4) Unless 6 is prime, 4 is prime.

Please provide the answers in the format [[];[];[];[]].

### Answer:
response:
Based on the provided logical rules and predicates, let's translate each proposition into a logical expression using the 0-ary predicate format:

(1) "2 is an even prime number" means that number 2, denoted symbolically in this context as "2", has both the property of being even and the property of being prime.
This can be written as: F(2) & G(2).

(2) "If 2 is prime, then 4 is not prime" can be symbolized as an implication where the antecedent is 2 being prime and the consequent is 4 not being prime.
This can be written as: G(2) ⇒ ∼G(4).

(3) "Only 2 is prime, for 6 to be prime" translates to the idea that 6 is prime only if 2 is also the only prime number given in the context.
This can be interpreted as a combined statement such that if 6 is prime, then it implies 2 is prime, and there is an implication taken from the fact that only 2 could exist with the property of being prime.
It can be written as: G(6) ⇒ (G(2) & ∼G(3) & ∼G(4) & ∼G(5) & ∼G(6)) but given the strategy of 0-ary predicates and for simplification, we can write: G(6) ⇒ G(2).

(4) "Unless 6 is prime, 4 is prime" can be understood as the contrapositive form of "If 4 is not prime, then 6 is not prime."
This could be written as: ∼G(6) ⇒ G(4), but adhering strictly to the statement as given, and understanding "unless" as a negation leading to an implication can be written directly as ∼G(6) ⇒ G(4).

Thus, the final answers as per the specified format:

[[F(2) & G(2)];[G(2) ⇒ ∼G(4)];[G(6) ⇒ G(2)];[∼G(6) ⇒ G(4)]].

- H(x,y): x and y have a common divisor greater than 1.

F(f(x, y), g(x, y))

### Answer:
response:
To solve the problem, we apply the logical operations according to the rule, given the interpretation 𝐽:

3. The function symbols and their implementations are:
   - fJ(x, y) = x + y (addition function)
   - gJ(x, y) = x * y (multiplication function)
4. The predicate symbol F and its implementation:
   - FJ(x, y) denotes x = y (equality predicate)

Given the formula F(f(x, y), g(x, y)), we:
- Replace f with fJ(x, y) = x + y.
- Replace g with gJ(x, y) = x * y.

Thus, we get the expression F(fJ(x, y), gJ(x, y)), which translates to F(x + y, x * y) and, according the definition of FJ, becomes (x + y) = (x * y) under interpretation 𝐽.

Therefore, the implementation of the given formula under interpretation 𝐽 is:

[[x + y = x * y]]

This is the required formula in the specified format.

- Write the predicate \( F(x + 2, y) \) using \( F_J \) as \( x + 2 = y \) and \( F(y + 2, x) \) as \( y + 2 = x \):

prompt:
You are an intelligent assistant that helps with various logical reasoning tasks. Below is a custom-defined rule for a specific type of logic. When responding, please ensure that your output adheres to the specified logical rules and format.

### Instructions:

1. Identify the relevant properties and objects as specified in the rule.
2. Apply the given logical operations or reasoning patterns.
3. Ensure your output is formatted according to the specified notation and symbols.

### Logic Rule:

The logical language 𝑀 consists of the following components:
1. A non-empty set of entities 𝐸;
2. Each entity constant a in 𝑀 has a corresponding entity a′ ∈ 𝐸, referred to as the assignment of a in 𝐽;
3. Each 𝑛-ary function symbol 𝑔 in 𝑀 has a function g𝐽, known as the implementation of 𝑔 in 𝐽;
4. Each 𝑛-ary predicate symbol 𝑅 in 𝑀 has a relation R𝐽, known as the implementation of 𝑅 in 𝐽.

Formulas 𝐵 under interpretation 𝐽:
1. Determine the entity set 𝐸;
2. Replace entity constants a in 𝐵 with a′;
3. Replace 𝑛-ary function symbols 𝑔 in 𝐵 with g𝐽;
4. Replace 𝑛-ary predicate symbols 𝑅 in 𝐵 with R𝐽.

The resulting formula is denoted as 𝐵𝐽, termed as the implementation of 𝐵 under 𝐽.

### Question:
(a) The non-empty set of entities E = natural numbers N.
(b) a′ = 2.
(c) Functions fJ(x, y) = x + y, gJ(x, y) = x * y.
(d) Predicate FJ(x, y) denotes x = y.

Write down the implementation of the following formulas under J:
(1) ∀x∀y∃zF(f(x,y),z)
(2) ∃xF(f(x,y),g(x,z)

Please provide the answer in [[];[]] format.

### Answer:
response:
To solve the problem, we will interpret each formula under the given interpretation \(J\) as described by the logical rules and convert them into a form that effectively uses the functions and the predicate as per the implementation in \(J\).

### Given Interpretation:
- \(E = \mathbb{N}\) (non-empty set of natural numbers)
- \(a' = 2\)
- \(f_J(x, y) = x + y\)
- \(g_J(x, y) = x * y\)
- \(F_J(x, y)\) denotes \(x = y\)

### For formula \((1)\) \(\forall x \forall y \exists z F(f(x,y),z)\):

- Replace \(f(x, y)\) with \(f_J(x, y)\) which means replacing \(f(x, y)\) with \(x + y\).
- This results in the formula becoming \(\forall x \forall y \exists z F(x + y, z)\).
- Substitute \(F(x, y)\) with \(F_J(x, y)\), which means replacing \(F(x + y, z)\) with \((x + y) = z\).

The resulting formula under \(J\) is \(\forall x \forall y \exists z (x + y = z)\).

This statement expresses that for any natural numbers \(x\) and \(y\), there exists a natural number \(z\) such that \(x + y = z\). This is indeed true in the natural numbers.

### For formula \((2)\) \(\exists x F(f(x,y),g(x,z))\):

- Replace \(f(x, y)\) with \(f_J(x, y)\), which means replacing \(f(x, y)\) with \(x + y\).
- Replace \(g(x, z)\) with \(g_J(x, z)\), which means replacing \(g(x, z)\) with \(x * z\).
- Substitute \(F(x, y)\) with \(F_J(x, y)\), which means replacing \(F(x + y, x * z)\) with \((x + y) = (x * z)\).

The resulting formula under \(J\) is \(\exists x (x + y = x * z)\).

This indicates that there exists a natural number \(x\) for which adding \(y\) to it equals multiplying \(x\) with \(z\).

### Answer in the requested format:

\[\[\forall x \forall y \exists z (x + y = z)\];\[\exists x (x + y = x * z)\]\]

title: Propositional Logic Concepts
rule_content:
Direct Propositions:
Reflect propositions that assert whether something does or does not possess a certain property, also known as property propositions or subject-predicate propositions.

Examples:
- [1] All metals are conductive.
- [2] Some products of labor are not commodities.

Composition of Direct Propositions:
- Subject (S): The term in the proposition that denotes the object being discussed. Examples include "metals" in [1] and "products of labor" in [2].
- Predicate (P): The term in the proposition that denotes the property of the object. Examples include "conductive" in [1] and "commodities" in [2].
- Connectives(C): Words that connect the subject and predicate.
    - Affirmative connective (e.g., "are"): Asserts that the subject possesses the property.
    - Negative connective (e.g., "are not"): Asserts that the subject does not possess the property.
- Quantifiers(Q): Words that indicate the quantity of objects referred to by the subject.
    - Universal quantifier (e.g., "all"): Indicates all members.
    - Particular quantifier (e.g., "some"): Indicates at least one member.

Logical Forms of Direct Propositions:
- Universal Affirmative (A): All S are P, abbreviated as SAP.
- Universal Negative (E): No S are P, abbreviated as SEP.
- Particular Affirmative (I): Some S are P, abbreviated as SIP.
- Particular Negative (O): Some S are not P, abbreviated as SOP.
- Singular Affirmative: a is P.
- Singular Negative: a is not P.

Relationships: 
The relationships between declarative propositions are based on the premise that the subject and predicate are identical. 
This identity is referred to as having the same subject (S) and predicate (P). 
There are four types of relationships as follows:
- * Relation:
    - Between A propositions and O propositions, E propositions and I propositions.
    - If one is true, the other is false; if one is false, the other is true.
- # Relation:
    - Between A propositions and E propositions.
    - If one is true, the other is false; if one is false, the other may be true or false.
- & Relation:
    - Between I propositions and O propositions.
    - If one is false, the other is true; if one is true, the other may be false or true.
- % Relation:
    - Between A propositions and I propositions, E propositions and O propositions.
    - If the universal proposition is true, the particular proposition is true; if the particular proposition is false, the universal proposition is false.

[[A];[A]] = [[*];[*]] = [A;A]

- Relationship between [3] and [4] is * (since one being true means the other is false).

[[B];[A]]

[[true];[false];[false];[false]]

- Definition: First perform obversion, and then perform conversion to transform the proposition.

question:
Person A: Hey, speaking is really an art, and not being able to speak well can easily offend people.
Person B: Oh? How so?
Person A: My grandfather is a case in point. He speaks very straightforwardly and often does good deeds with bad intentions. I remember one time he invited some friends over for dinner.
Person B: That's nice, everyone can get together.
Person A: The appointment was for six in the evening, and by half past five, three people had arrived, but one important guest hadn't shown up yet.
Person B: Then wait a bit longer, if they don't come, start eating without them.
Person A: My grandfather is a punctual person. When it was half past six and that guest still hadn't arrived, he got anxious and said to himself, "The ones who should come are not those who come." As a result, one of the guests got upset, thinking they were the one who shouldn't have come, and left.
Person B: That's really a misunderstanding.
Person A: With two guests left, my grandfather was still waiting, and then he said, "The ones who have left were the ones who should have stayed." Another guest felt there was no sincerity and also left.
Person B: How could he say that, another one left.
Person A: The last one was my grandfather's old friend, who advised my grandfather to be careful with his words. My grandfather explained that he wasn't talking about him, but the old friend also felt that they were the one who shouldn't stay, and left too.
Person B: This dinner really was, everyone left.

"The ones who should come are not those who come." by method B, we get?

Be careful to maintain consistency with the original sentence.

question:

needle: - Belief Axiom: `B_p → p`, indicating that if someone firmly believes `p` is true, it can be inferred that `p` is indeed true.
title: Epistemic Logic
rule_content:
Symbol Definitions:
- Belief (`B_p`): Indicates that an individual firmly believes the proposition `p` is true.
- Common Belief (`G_p`): Indicates that the proposition `p` is a common belief within the group `G`, meaning all members collectively believe `p`.
- Doubt (`H_p`): Indicates that an individual harbors doubt about the truth of the proposition `p`.

Cognitive Logic Model:
Cognitive logic simulates the interaction between different worlds and beliefs through the construction of models:
- Model (`M`): Composed of three parts:
    - Set of Worlds (`W`): All possible worlds.
    - Accessibility Relation (`R`): If `iRj`, it means individual `i` can recognize the belief state of individual `j`.
    - Truth Value Function of Propositions (`V`): Defines the truth value of each proposition in each world.

Definition of Common Belief:
If `p` is a common belief in the group `G`, then for every member `i` of the group, `B_ip` holds.

Cognitive Logic Axioms:

1. Basic Axioms
- Belief Axiom: `B_p → p`, indicating that if someone firmly believes `p` is true, it can be inferred that `p` is indeed true.

2. Advanced Axioms
- Axiom of Reflexivity: `B_p → BB_p`, indicating that if an individual firmly believes the proposition `p`, they also believe they believe `p`.
- Axiom of Transitivity: If `iRj` and `B_ip`, then `B_jp`, indicating that if individual `i` firmly believes the proposition `p` and can recognize individual `j`, then `j` also believes `p`.
- Axiom of Consistent Belief: `B_p ∧ B_{¬p} → ⊥`, indicating that an individual cannot simultaneously believe in a proposition `p` and its negation `¬p`, as this would lead to a logical contradiction.

3. Axioms of Doubt
- Introduction of Doubt: `H_p → ¬B_p`, indicating that if an individual doubts the proposition `p`, they do not firmly believe `p`.
- Spread of Doubt: If `iRj` and `H_ip`, then `H_jp`, indicating that if individual `i` doubts the proposition `p` and can recognize individual `j`, then `j` may also start to doubt `p`.

### Logic Rule:

Symbol Definitions:
- Belief (`B_p`): Indicates that an individual firmly believes the proposition `p` is true.
- Common Belief (`G_p`): Indicates that the proposition `p` is a common belief within the group `G`, meaning all members collectively believe `p`.
- Doubt (`H_p`): Indicates that an individual harbors doubt about the truth of the proposition `p`.

Cognitive Logic Model:
Cognitive logic simulates the interaction between different worlds and beliefs through the construction of models:
- Model (`M`): Composed of three parts:
    - Set of Worlds (`W`): All possible worlds.
    - Accessibility Relation (`R`): If `iRj`, it means individual `i` can recognize the belief state of individual `j`.
    - Truth Value Function of Propositions (`V`): Defines the truth value of each proposition in each world.

Definition of Common Belief:
If `p` is a common belief in the group `G`, then for every member `i` of the group, `B_ip` holds.

Cognitive Logic Axioms:

1. Basic Axioms
- Belief Axiom: `B_p → p`, indicating that if someone firmly believes `p` is true, it can be inferred that `p` is indeed true.

2. Advanced Axioms
- Axiom of Reflexivity: `B_p → BB_p`, indicating that if an individual firmly believes the proposition `p`, they also believe they believe `p`.
- Axiom of Transitivity: If `iRj` and `B_ip`, then `B_jp`, indicating that if individual `i` firmly believes the proposition `p` and can recognize individual `j`, then `j` also believes `p`.
- Axiom of Consistent Belief: `B_p ∧ B_{¬p} → ⊥`, indicating that an individual cannot simultaneously believe in a proposition `p` and its negation `¬p`, as this would lead to a logical contradiction.

3. Axioms of Doubt
- Introduction of Doubt: `H_p → ¬B_p`, indicating that if an individual doubts the proposition `p`, they do not firmly believe `p`.
- Spread of Doubt: If `iRj` and `H_ip`, then `H_jp`, indicating that if individual `i` doubts the proposition `p` and can recognize individual `j`, then `j` may also start to doubt `p`.

### Question:
According to the Axiom of Reflexivity, what does it mean if Alice firmly believes a certain proposition to be true?

A. Alice may have doubts about this proposition.
B. Alice is convinced that she herself is convinced of this proposition.
C. Alice and other people are all aware of this proposition.

Please provide the answers in the format [[A/B/C]].

### Answer:
response:
[[B]]

According to the Axiom of Reflexivity (`B_p → BB_p`), if Alice firmly believes a certain proposition to be true (`B_p`), it logically follows that Alice is also convinced that she herself is convinced of this proposition (`BB_p`). Thus, the correct answer is B.

Symbol Definitions:
- Belief (`B_p`): Indicates that an individual firmly believes the proposition `p` is true.
- Common Belief (`G_p`): Indicates that the proposition `p` is a common belief within the group `G`, meaning all members collectively believe `p`.
- Doubt (`H_p`): Indicates that an individual harbors doubt about the truth of the proposition `p`.

Cognitive Logic Model:
Cognitive logic simulates the interaction between different worlds and beliefs through the construction of models:
- Model (`M`): Composed of three parts:
    - Set of Worlds (`W`): All possible worlds.
    - Accessibility Relation (`R`): If `iRj`, it means individual `i` can recognize the belief state of individual `j`.
    - Truth Value Function of Propositions (`V`): Defines the truth value of each proposition in each world.

Definition of Common Belief:
If `p` is a common belief in the group `G`, then for every member `i` of the group, `B_ip` holds.

Cognitive Logic Axioms:

1. Basic Axioms
- Belief Axiom: `B_p → p`, indicating that if someone firmly believes `p` is true, it can be inferred that `p` is indeed true.

2. Advanced Axioms
- Axiom of Reflexivity: `B_p → BB_p`, indicating that if an individual firmly believes the proposition `p`, they also believe they believe `p`.
- Axiom of Transitivity: If `iRj` and `B_ip`, then `B_jp`, indicating that if individual `i` firmly believes the proposition `p` and can recognize individual `j`, then `j` also believes `p`.
- Axiom of Consistent Belief: `B_p ∧ B_{¬p} → ⊥`, indicating that an individual cannot simultaneously believe in a proposition `p` and its negation `¬p`, as this would lead to a logical contradiction.

3. Axioms of Doubt
- Introduction of Doubt: `H_p → ¬B_p`, indicating that if an individual doubts the proposition `p`, they do not firmly believe `p`.
- Spread of Doubt: If `iRj` and `H_ip`, then `H_jp`, indicating that if individual `i` doubts the proposition `p` and can recognize individual `j`, then `j` may also start to doubt `p`.

### Question:
If Alice is skeptical about the library being open today, and Bob can acknowledge Alice's skepticism, what is Bob likely to be convinced of, based on the Spread of Doubt axiom?

A. That the library is open today.
B. That the library is closed today.
C. That he may also begin to doubt whether the library is open today.

Please provide the answers in the format [[A/B/C]].

### Answer:
response:
Given the Spread of Doubt axiom (`If iRj and H_ip, then H_jp`), where `iRj` indicates that individual `i` can acknowledge individual `j`, and `H_ip` means that individual `i` harbors doubt about the proposition `p`:

1. Alice (individual `i`) is skeptical (`H_ip`) about the library being open today (`p`).
2. Bob (individual `j`) can acknowledge Alice's skepticism (`iRj`).

Based on the Spread of Doubt axiom, Bob may start to doubt the proposition as well (`H_jp`).

Therefore, Bob is likely to begin doubting whether the library is open today.

[[C]]

### Question:
If a proposition p is the consensus of the group G, 
but the individual Alice doubts this proposition, 
what logical expression can be written according to the definition of consensus?

Please give your answer in the format [[]].

### Answer:
response:
Given the conditions:
1. A proposition \( p \) is accepted as a consensus of the group \( G \). 
2. The group consensus being true can be denoted as common belief, `G_p`.

3. Alice harbors doubt regarding the proposition \( p \), which can be expressed as `H_p` (Alice doubts \( p \)).

According to the logical axioms provided, we know that `H_p → ¬B_p`, meaning that if Alice doubts the proposition \( p \), she does not firmly believe it (`¬B_p`).

Combining this with the definition of common belief where `G_p` implies that each individual in the group believes \( p \), and considering Alice is part of group \( G \), the existence of Alice’s doubt introduces a contradiction to the common belief `G_p`, because if \( p \) was truly a common belief of the group, Alice would not doubt it.

Thus, if Alice doubts the proposition \( p \) and it is claimed that \( p \) is a consensus of the group \( G \), the logical inconsistency can be expressed as an evident contradiction `⊥` (falsehood).

Therefore, the logical expression representing the situation where Alice doubts the consensus is:

```plaintext
[GG_p ∧ H_p → ⊥]
```

This expression denotes that if \( p \) is a common belief of the entire group \( G \) (`GG_p` for clarity), and Alice harbors doubt about \( p \) (`H_p`), then this leads to a contradiction or falsehood (`⊥`).

needle: - Necessity Operator: `[ c ]φ` indicates that after executing command `c`, the proposition `φ` will necessarily be true.
title: Dynamic Logic
rule_content:
1.Symbol Definitions
- Command: `c` represents a basic operation within a program.
- Proposition: `φ` represents a statement or condition.
- Program State: Represents the system state after the execution of a command.

2.Dynamic Operators
- Necessity Operator: `[ c ]φ` indicates that after executing command `c`, the proposition `φ` will necessarily be true.
- Possibility Operator: `⟨ c ⟩φ` indicates that after executing command `c`, the proposition `φ` may be true.

3.Axioms and Rules
- Substitution Rule:If `c` behaves the same as `d`, then `[ c ]φ` is equivalent to `[ d ]φ`.
- Sequence Rule:`[ c_1; c_2 ]φ` is equivalent to `[ c_1 ][ c_2 ]φ`.
- Choice Rule:`[ c_1 + c_2 ]φ` is equivalent to `([ c_1 ]φ ∨ [ c_2 ]φ)`.
- Loop Rule:For the loop command `c*`, `[ c* ]φ` is equivalent to `φ ∨ ([ c ][ c* ]φ)`.
- Concurrent Rule:If `c_1` and `c_2` can be executed concurrently, then `⟨ c_1 || c_2 ⟩φ` is equivalent to `⟨ c_1 ⟩⟨ c_2 ⟩φ ∨ ⟨ c_2 ⟩⟨ c_1 ⟩φ`.
- Interruption Rule:If `c_1` can interrupt `c_2`, then `⟨ c_1; c_2 ⟩φ` is equivalent to `⟨ c_1 ⟩φ`.
- Exception Rule:If `c` may trigger an exception `e`, then `[ c ]φ` is equivalent to `([ c ]φ ∧ [ e ]φ)`.
- Resource Limitation Rule:If the command `c` is subject to resource limitation `R`, then `[ c ]φ` is equivalent to `(R ∧ [ c ]φ)`.
- Dependency Rule:If the execution of `c_1` depends on `c_2`, then `[ c_1 ]φ` is equivalent to `[ c_2 ][ c_1 ]φ`.
- Priority Rule:If `c_1` has higher priority than `c_2`, then `⟨ c_1; c_2 ⟩φ` is equivalent to `⟨ c_1 ⟩⟨ c_2 ⟩φ`.
- History Rule:If the execution of `c` depends on the historical command `h`, then `[ c ]φ` is equivalent to `[ h ][ c ]φ`.
- Prediction Rule:If the system can predict the outcome of `c`, then `[ c ]φ` is equivalent to `[ predict(c) ]φ`.

`⟨⟨c1⟩⟨c2⟩⟩φ`

A. * inductive reasoning

The reasoning used in the question is an example of * (regular) induction rather than Φ induction because the conclusion is drawn from observing only some instances (the six different apples) and generalizing that all members of the class (all apples) share the property (being red). While Φ induction would require examining every single member of the class to draw a conclusion about all members, in this scenario, we do not claim that all apples in existence have been observed. Therefore, this is an example of * inductive reasoning.

needle: - If S and P occur together in multiple cases while other conditions A, B, C, E, F, etc., differ:

title: Logical Methods for Exploring Cause and Effect Relationships
rule_content:
Five Methods for Exploring Causal Relationships

1. Method ⸮:
- If S and P occur together in multiple cases while other conditions A, B, C, E, F, etc., differ:
    - (1) S A B     P
    - (2) S C D     P
    - (3) S E F     P
    - ...
    - Therefore, S and P may have a causal relationship.

2. Method ؆:
- If P occurs when S is present and does not occur when S is absent:
    - (1) S A B     P
    - (2) - A B     P
    - Therefore, S and P may have a causal relationship.

3. Method ꙮ:
- Positive group: S and P occur together, while other conditions A, B, C, D, E, F, etc., differ:
    - Positive group
        - (1) S A B     P
        - (2) S C D    P
        - (3) S E F     P
    - Negative group: S is absent, P is also absent, and other conditions A, C, D, E, F, etc., differ:
        - Negative group
            - (1') - A C    -
            - (2') - D E    -
            - (3') - B F    -
    - Therefore, S and P may have a causal relationship.

4. Method ⵣ:
- When changes in S correspond to changes in P:
    - (1) S1 A B     P1
    - (2) S2 A B    P2
    - (3) S3 A B    P3
    - ...
    - Therefore, S and P may have a causal relationship.

5. Method ⚘:
- When S, A, B, C have causal relationships with P, X, Y, Z, and the causal relationships between A and X, B and Y, C and Z are known:
    - (1) A has a causal relationship with X
    - (2) B has a causal relationship with Y
    - (3) C has a causal relationship with Z
    - Therefore, S and P may have a causal relationship.

### Question:
People rub their frozen hands together, and their hands become warm; 
people strike cold stones, and the stones can spark; 
people continuously hammer an iron block, and the iron block can also become red-hot. From this, it can be inferred that the movement of objects can generate heat.

The causal derivation of this discourse fits which method:
A.⸮ method   B.؆ method   C.ꙮ method    D.ⵣ method   E.⚘ method

Please give your answer in [[A/B/C/D/E]] format.

### Answer:
response:
The given scenario describes a general observation where different objects (hands, stones, iron) becoming warm or generating heat through movement or action (rubbing, striking, hammering). It fits the pattern of observing multiple instances where a cause (movement) leads to an effect (generation of heat) while the specific conditions under which this happens can differ. This aligns with Method ⸮, as outlined in the rule set, which considers the occurrence of an outcome (P) with a consistent causative factor (S) under various changing conditions (A, B, C, etc.).

Therefore, the answer is [[A]].

question:
At the Southern Experiment Station of the University of California, USA, Chinese hybrid rice varieties were tested against American rice varieties twice, in 1980 and 1981. 
The temperature, fertiliser, water, soil and management methods were the same, but the only difference was the sub-seed. 
The results of the trial planting: in 1980, the average harvest of hybrid rice in China was 737 mcm per mu, while that of the U.S. variety rice was 279.25 mcm per mu; in 1981, the average harvest of hybrid rice in China was 783.15 mcm per mu, while that of the U.S. variety rice was 279.35 mcm per mu.

A. ⸮ method B. ؆ method C. ꙮ method D. ⵣ method E. ⚘ method

Please give your answer in [[A/B/C/D/E]] format.
